places.generalDescription: Bara Imambara, also known as Asafi Imambara, is a grand architectural marvel built by Nawab Asaf-ud-Daula in the late 18th century. This historical monument in Lucknow features a large mosque, a labyrinth called Bhul Bhulaiya, and a stepwell with running water. The central hall of Bara Imambara is renowned as the largest vaulted chamber globally and is devoid of any woodwork except for its interior galleries.

sources.snippet: Counted among the top historical places in Lucknow, Bara Imambara aka Asafi Imambara is a historical monument that dates back to 1784. Built by Asaf-ud-Daula, one of the renowned Nawabs of Awadh, the complex comprises a large mosque (Asfi Mosque), a labyrinth (the Bhul Bhulaiya), and a stepwell with running water (Shahi Baoli). The structure boasts of two large gateways that will lead you to the central hall, which is touted to be the largest vaulted chamber in the world.

reviews.text:
A Must-Visit Historic Wonder in Lucknow! üïå‚ú®

Visited the Bara Imambara and was truly amazed! üòç
The architecture is stunning - the central hall is massive with no pillars supporting the ceiling. It's hard to believe it was built in the 1700s! üèõÔ∏èüí´üì∏ Perfect spot for photography, history lovers, and peaceful walks.
üéüÔ∏è Ticket price is reasonable, and the place is well-maintained.
‚ú® Bonus: The view from the rooftop is fantastic!

‚úÖ Unique experience in Lucknow

Will definitely visit again with friends or family. üë®‚Äçüë©‚Äçüëß‚Äçüë¶

Historical mugal palace and worship place at Lucknow. The Bhool Bhulaiya in Bara Imambara in Lucknow is a labyrinth of interconnected tunnels, with each path branching into many others and only one leads to the exit. It is a must visit as the exiting the labyrinth will be challenging and time consuming. Place is maintained well and organised crowd management by the authorities are appreciative.

A place with picture worthy views but  mismanaged by authorities

I was born in Lucknow, and I am a local.
Today I visited the Imambara 3rd time in my life, last visit was in 2008 and these are the below things I observed.
1. There is no  baggage or security check. This place is piece of cake for any one with bad intentions or wants to cause havoc.
2. Ticket price for adults is INR 50 which is ok but for visiting the roof area or the bhool bhulaiyaa, a guide has to be hired which will cost minimum INR 100.
3. Before entering the Imambara or the bhool bhulaiya everyone must deposit his/her shoes outside the inner Imambara entrance and the men at the deposit counter will say "jo dena ho dede" which means the price for security deposit is not fixed and they mostly keep shoes and slippers in open. If there is rain the shoes can get wet. There is no proper cloak room.
4. Since taking guide is mandatory for bhool bhulaiya we had to forcefully do so and the guide will take you and show you the various holy things kept in Imambara. The guide that we got was named Raja Hindustani and his diction was not at all clear. He took us on the narrow paths made of the dome of the Imambara without footwear and there was no lights and the floor is broken at places and can cause cuts and bruises. The maintenance of this place is worst I have ever experienced. I will suggest not to take small kids here and that too on a weekend. My 4 year daughter was feeling scared and also this place is not for claustrophobic people.
5. Our guide passed a comment too on my wife which she opposed and yelled at him after which our group consisting of 40 people praised and clapped for my wife as she vented out at the guide who all the group members were forced to follow even though his way of explaining things or tackling crowd was pathetic. Many women came and told my wife " good you shouted at him " as all of the people were frustrated but not speaking up against the unruly behaviour of the guide.
6. Since the roof is all stones and everywhere it is hard and uneven , walking on it for kids is very hard and chances of getting hurt are high.
7. Nevertheless it is a picturesque place and if you hire a proper guide who takes more money your experience can be better but the forced guide system and no light being in the narrow pathways is risky for women.
The forced guide will charge INR 150 for complete tour.
8. Now my next visit maybe after next 15 16 years and if given a chance may not visit at all.
I love Lucknow for the food and culture but at present taking some outsider to this place may only cause you embarrassment. They should install lights in dark pathways and remove the mandate of removing shoes on the roof of the building as it causes huge discomfort to tourists. The renovation from outside makes the building look pretty.

places.name: Rumi Darwaza

reviews.text:
Rumi Darwaza, one of Lucknow's most iconic landmarks, stands as a majestic symbol of the city's rich Nawabi heritage and architectural brilliance. Built in 1784 by Nawab Asaf-ud-Daula during a period of severe famine, the structure not only provided employment to thousands but also left behind a masterpiece that continues to awe visitors centuries later. Often referred to as the ‚ÄúTurkish Gate‚Äù due to its Awadhi architectural style inspired by Turkish design, the Rumi Darwaza rises to a height of 60 feet, with a striking arched gateway and intricately carved floral motifs adorning its surface.

Sadly, in recent years, the monument has undergone a round of repainting rather than proper restoration. The use of modern paints, rather than historically accurate conservation techniques, has slightly dulled its original charm. Yet, even this cosmetic intervention hasn't managed to mask its beauty. The gateway still exudes elegance and grandeur.

What makes Rumi Darwaza even more intriguing is its resemblance to the shape of a traditional necklace - and to those familiar with Lucknow's textile artistry, it uncannily echoes the layout of a chikan kurta design. It's a bridge between architecture and culture, the physical and the artistic. Despite changes over time, Rumi Darwaza continues to be a proud emblem of Lucknow's past and present.

Recently Visiting Rumi Darwaza in Lucknow is an awesome old Awadhi architecture. The marvelous carvings and grand design make it a beautiful sight. It resemble to the shape of a traditional necklace and pendant. It's considered one of the proud emblem and most photogenic spots of Lucknow. If you are in Lucknow please don't miss here to take a picture. Visit this place in early hours for good pictures and avoid crowd. After Delhi and Agra I found architecturally beautiful city is Lucknow. As the name suggests itself and some people called it the Turkish Gate. Must visit.

1.Architectural Beauty:
Visitors often praise the Rumi Darwaza for its grand design and detailed carvings. Many call it a "masterpiece of Awadhi architecture."

2. Perfect for Photography:
Tourists love clicking photos here. It's considered one of the most photogenic spots in Lucknow, especially in the early morning or at sunset.

3. Historical Importance:
Many people appreciate the deep historical value of the gate. They mention it transports you to the era of Nawabs and Mughal influences.

4. Central Location:
Since it's located in the heart of Lucknow, it's easy to combine a visit with other nearby attractions like Bada Imambara and Chota Imambara.

5. Mixed Notes on Maintenance:
Some reviewers feel that while the structure itself is stunning, better maintenance (especially cleanliness around the area) could make the experience even better

The Hussainabad Clock Tower is truly a beautiful landmark in Lucknow. The architecture is stunning, with intricate details that make it stand out, especially when seen up close. It's well-maintained, and the surrounding area has a nice historic charm. Visiting in the evening is extra special - the lighting makes it even more picturesque. A great spot for history lovers, photography, or just a peaceful walk while soaking in the old-world vibe of the city.

In the resplendent city of Lucknow, a towering marvel of modernity pierces the sky ‚Äì the illustrious Clock Tower, a masterpiece of Moorish design, erstwhile believed to be the largest in the Indian subcontinent. This magnificent edifice, a symphony of stone and steel, is illuminated by a dazzling array of lamps, its beauty further enhanced by the melodic chime of five bells, whose sweet peals echo through the air. Standing tall at 221 feet, this grandiose structure is an exemplar of traditional British architecture, rivaling the iconic Big Ben of London in both splendor and majesty. Its colossal wheels, a marvel of engineering, surpass even those of its London counterpart.

Conceived by the visionary architect of those times- Richard Roskell Bayne, this monumental clock tower was erected at a cost of two lakhs, funded by the benevolent Trustees of the Husainabad Endowment, who wisely invested the legacy of thirty-six lakhs of rupees bequeathed by the illustrious Muhammad Ali Shah, third King of Oudh. Bayne's masterpiece, a testament to his ingenuity, boasts a intricate machinery comprising wrought-iron sides, gun-metal wheels, and hardened steel pinions, precision-crafted to ensure unwavering accuracy.

This majestic timepiece, a true marvel of modern science, stands as a shining beacon, a testament to the confluence of art and engineering. Its grandeur is a reflection of Bayne's prolific career, which spanned the construction of bridges, train stations, and bungalows, as well as monumental buildings such as the East India Railway Office, New Market in Kolkata, and Oak Grove School in Mussoorie. His legacy extends to the Thornhill and Mayne Memorial Library and Mayo Memorial in Allahabad, a testament to his enduring impact on India's architectural landscape.

places.generalDescription: Chota Imambara, also known as the Imambara Hussainabad Mubarak, is a visually stunning Muslim congregation hall and mausoleum located just west of the Bara Imambara in Lucknow. Built in 1838 by Muhammad Ali Shah, it was initially intended as a congregation hall for the Shia community's devotees but later became the Nawab and his mother's mausoleum.

sources.snippet: Another congregation complex of the Shia Muslim sect, The Chota Imambara was built in 1838 by Nawab Muhammad Shah Ali. Right outside the complex also lays the 4 storied Satkhanda, an unfinished watchtower or observatory which was supposed to have 7 stories.

Being in Lucknow, you absolutely have to see the Chota Imambara, also known as the "Palace of Lights." It's a collection of buildings that really shows how old and fancy Lucknow is. It is in the old part of the city, near the famous Bara Imambara and Rumi Darwaza. Inside, there's a mosque, a tomb, a clock tower, a garden, and even a pond. The main building, the Imambara itself, is where Nawab Muhammad Ali Shah and his mother are buried. Shia Muslims gather here during Muharram.
Start by seeing the Rumi Darwaza, Clock Tower, and Satkhanda first, as they're outside and free to explore. You can buy a combined ticket from the Bara Imambara ticket counter for just ‚Çπ50, which covers the Bara Imambara (including the Bhool Bhulaiya and Bouli), the Chota Imambara (including the Shahi Hamam), and the Picture Gallery. There are separate fees for cameras.
Each spot has its own special charm, but remember, you can't take photos or videos inside the Imambara building itself. The grounds are beautifully kept, with lovely ponds, ornate gates, stylish lamps, and colorful gardens. It's a place that draws visitors from all over the world to admire its architecture, art, and history.
To really appreciate it, it's a good idea to read up on its history beforehand, or you can hire a guide. Parking is available nearby, and the place is wheelchair accessible. Plan to spend at least an hour exploring. You will not regret it!!

reviews.text: One of the prominent attractions of Lucknow city. It served as the residence for the British Resident General and has the ruins of a British settlement at the time of the 1857 uprising. Place is clean and huge and has quiet surroundings. You can see a lot of small birds and squirrels and also has a small museum with lots of information on display. Some trees are so huge they will be easily over 200-300 years old. A must visit if you love history!!

Having lived in Lucknow all my life, I had visited The Residency as a child but never truly explored it. Recently, I finally took the time to revisit this historic gem - and I'm so glad I did.

The moment you step inside, you're transported to a time that shaped India's history. The ruins, still marked with bullet holes and cannon fire, silently narrate the intensity of the 1857 revolt. Each structure within the complex - from the Baillie Guard Gate and Treasury to the church ruins and underground chambers - holds a haunting charm.

Walking through the wide lawns and shaded pathways, I spent time at the museum, the graveyard, and the many crumbling buildings that once formed the heart of British residency life. The view from the top of some of the structures is breathtaking, and the atmosphere is both peaceful and reflective.

It's not just a monument, it's a memory - of resilience, history, and a city that has seen so much. If you're in Lucknow, The Residency deserves your time and attention.

reviews.text:
A Roaring Good Time for the Whole Family!

I recently visited the Nawab Wajid Ali Shah lucknow Zoo, and i had an absolute blast!
As i walked through the gates, we were immediately struck by the sheer variety of animals on display. From majestic lions and tigers to playful monkeys, there's something for everyone at this fantastic zoo.

What truly impressed me, however, was the zoo's commitment to animal welfare and conservation. The enclosures are spacious and well-maintained, providing the animals with a safe and healthy environment.

While the zoo is generally well-maintained, there are a few areas where it could improve. For example, some of the signage could be clearer, and the food options could be more varied.
Overall, I would highly recommend the Nawab Wajid Ali Shah Zoo to anyone looking for a fun and educational day out. With its incredible variety of animals, spacious enclosures, and family-friendly atmosphere, it's a must-visit destination for anyone in Lucknow!

Standout Features:
Variety of Animals: The zoo is home to over 1,000 animals from around the world, including some rare and endangered species.

Spacious Enclosures: The zoo's commitment to animal welfare is evident in the spacious and well-maintained enclosures.

Family-Friendly: The zoo offers a range of activities and attractions for kids, making it a great destination for families.

Tips and Insights:
Best Time to Visit: Early morning or late afternoon, when the sun isn't too harsh.

Wear Comfortable Shoes: You'll want to explore every corner of this fantastic zoo!

Bring Water and Snacks: Stay hydrated and energized throughout your visit.

reviews.text:
Beautiful Eco friendly project of developing the Gomti riverbed side area into a picturesque site.
Nice for jogging and walking. One of the most visited tourist attractions in the Lucknow city. Colourful flowerbeds are so cute. Ample car parking is available.

The Gomti Riverfront is honestly one of the most peaceful and scenic spots in Lucknow. It's beautifully maintained with clean walkways, lush green parks, and the whole vibe feels super refreshing, especially during the evenings. The lighting along the river makes it look magical after sunset. Whether you're into morning walks, photography, or just want to sit by the water and relax, this place is perfect. Great spot to chill with friends or even go for a solo stroll. Highly recommend visiting at dusk!

Lucknow's Gomti Riverfront project has changed the riverside  into a much nicer place for people to visit and relax. It has made the Gomti River a place people can enjoy again.
Imagine a peaceful break from the busy city. That is what the riverfront offers. You can relax, feel refreshed, and be close to nature by the Gomti River.
There is plenty to do there. You can walk or bike on paths, sit in gardens, play in recreational areas, and grab a bite from food stalls. Plus, they've got restrooms and parking.
The only real problem is the river itself. Sometimes, a bad smell comes and goes, which can be unpleasant. But, when it's not smelly, it is a great place to unwind and spend some good time. The park was almost empty during our visit probably because of the smell. Gomti Riverfront Park has toilets, but only at the parking site. There are no toilets within the park itself. The best time  for the tourists to visit it is in the evening with lit up colourful lights. Nice place to relax and enjoy.

places.generalDescription: Satkhanda is an iconic watchtower located in Lucknow, dating back to the 1800s. It was intended to be a seven-story structure but remains incomplete at four stories due to the untimely demise of King Mohammed Ali Shah, who initiated its construction. The red-brick tower features Islamic design details and bears resemblance to the Leaning Tower of Pisa. Despite being unfinished, it stands as a marvelous piece of architecture and is a popular attraction for visitors in Lucknow.

reviews.text: Satkhanda is an unfinished four-story building. Raja Mohammad Ali Shah started building it between 1837 and 1842.  He died suddenly, and the building was never finished. People think it is bad luck because someone died while it was being built.  It is still just four stories tall located near the Rumi Darwaza and Bara Imambara. It would have been an amazing structure if it had been finished.

Satkhanda in Lucknow is both historically intriguing and visually stunning. It would have been a more amazing structure if it had been finished. The name suggests seven stories but it has four stories. Local guide said that the ruler wanted to make it like leaning tower of pizza in Italy but could not make it. It is one of the interesting monuments to see in Lucknow.

AN incomplete tower planned to be built was stopped midway. Even with this incomplete building, it looks stunning, could only imagine what it would have looked like if it had been completed. Though, it's in quite a neglect today and not properly take care of

places.generalDescription: Jama Masjid, located in the vibrant Tahseenganj area of Lucknow, Uttar Pradesh, is a stunning mosque complex that showcases intricate sandstone craftsmanship and an impressive array of pillars and domes. Constructed under the reign of King Mohammad Ali Shah in 1839 AD, this architectural marvel was designed to rival its namesake in Delhi. The mosque beautifully blends Hindu and Muslim design elements, featuring elaborate carvings inspired by Jain culture.

places.name: Jama Masjid

reviews.text:
185 years old masjid in Lucknow. Such an attractive monument. Visited on Friday morning. Calm and peaceful environment. Prayed myself and just another person. Big and spacious area. Surrounding area will rejoice your mind with praise to Allah and the builder.  For your Lucknow City Tour. It is best to start from here. Gate was open. No security, no restriction. Wazukhana located in the eastern side. Spend near 1 hour just by siting and viewing the structure. Must recommended in your Lucknow Tour.

Best way to reach via an ola/rapido bike from Charbagh station, time: 10-20 minutes, Fare: 60 rupees.

This mosque is located in the area of Husainabad, Lucknow. The construction of this mosque was started in the year 1839 A.D. by Muhammad Ali Shah, third Badshah of Awadh with the intention to surpass the Jama Masjid at Delhi in size, but after his death the mosque was completed by his wife Queen Malika Jahan Sahiba in the year 1845 A.D.[1]. One can see Indo Islamic architecture. This mosque is opened for Muslims only. The prayer hall is surmounted by three pear-shaped high double domes decorated with an inverted lotus on the top and is also flanked by two octagonal four-storeyed tapering minarets on either side.
A very beautiful Shia mosque located and accessed by an alleyway. Surrounding are residential buildings and a Mausoleum

places.generalDescription: Dilkusha Kothi is a historical monument in Lucknow that showcases the magnificence of Baroque architecture. Built in the 19th century by Saadat Ali Khan, it is an exact replica of the English country house Seaton Delavel, constructed in 1721. This architectural gem stands out among Lucknow's monuments for its unique style, surrounded by beautifully designed gardens.

sources.snippet: Dilkusha Kothi displays evidence of the architectural variety of the city as a hidden gem in Lucknow‚Äôs historical variety. Constructed in the early 1800s, this charming building functioned as a hunting lodge and a haven for British colonists throughout their time in the colonies. Dilkusha Kothi, which is covered up on the banks of the Gomti River, is home to an exquisite example of Moorish and Gothic architecture.

Good environment tourist vist in these places please on winter after February there weather like june july allover great experience and amazing experience lucknow the city of nawab

Dilkhusha Kothi is honestly one of those underrated spots in Lucknow that gives total old-school royal vibes. I went there on a quiet afternoon, and the moment I entered, I felt like I had just time-travelled back into history. The structure is in ruins but still looks so beautiful and grand ‚Äì you can imagine how royal it must've been back in the day.

The place is super peaceful, barely any crowd, and surrounded by greenery. I just walked around slowly, soaking in the old architecture and taking some cool photos ‚Äì perfect spot for anyone who loves historic vibes. And the best part is, it's not commercialized or noisy like other places. Just calm, raw, and real.

If you ever want a chill place to explore that also connects you with Lucknow's past, then this is the spot. Pure peaceful vibe and a solid escape from the city chaos.
